messages: df899a89abd846dc05a29ddcfcaa11de (01:30): truedfx: [!-~] is anycharacter but '-' and '~'
98c3586f543e22ae490af43b98a902bd (01:30): i thought that would be [^-~] in most things
98c3586f543e22ae490af43b98a902bd (01:31): i'd expect [!-~] to be any of those 3
74c761012c0f07003f60498f0c4eaf8c (01:32): there we go, echo "dar" | sed -e 's:[!ad]\+::' # does something sane.
98c3586f543e22ae490af43b98a902bd (01:33): if it's a range, though, ranges are inclusive
9c34d2106e2ca0c750809548a82b02b5 (01:33): sed: -e expression #1, char 10: Invalid range end
74c761012c0f07003f60498f0c4eaf8c (01:33): hmm. crappy example on my part, should've set it to [!ae] (differing results)...
df899a89abd846dc05a29ddcfcaa11de (01:33): ah, you guys talk sed... sorry :-)
74c761012c0f07003f60498f0c4eaf8c (01:34): bash has hte bastardized regex, not sed/grep ;)
3818b509e1d85f7608abd57eb70206bf (01:34): bash doesn't even have regex (unless you do shopt -s extglob, and then it has crazy syntax)
df899a89abd846dc05a29ddcfcaa11de (01:34): truedfx: works for sed as well
df899a89abd846dc05a29ddcfcaa11de (01:34): you guys need to remember that you need to escape the [
df899a89abd846dc05a29ddcfcaa11de (01:35): otherwise bash will catch it :-)
3818b509e1d85f7608abd57eb70206bf (01:37): ferringb, ah, right... Well, the original was [^!-~], so there it shouldn't cause that problem
80e8e52c4fc166e1c41b1aefbe0543ba (01:37): otherwise it's trying to do a range
3818b509e1d85f7608abd57eb70206bf (01:37): agaffney, it's meant to be a range
80e8e52c4fc166e1c41b1aefbe0543ba (01:38): eh? how does that work? ASCII values?
3818b509e1d85f7608abd57eb70206bf (01:38): agaffney, right, it removes all spaces and control characters (and non-ASCII characters)
3818b509e1d85f7608abd57eb70206bf (01:39): ! is the first non-space non-control character, and ~ is the last (in ASCII)
43624a444f6e22bc029b06dd14a23897 (01:39): one more reason to use POSIX character classes then
c66f94aef4ae3d1e815b70f7f3440862 (01:39): yikes what did I walk into
312c60a696ee6c11196fb7da47743b17 (01:49): is there a way to pass an arguemnt to epatch?
312c60a696ee6c11196fb7da47743b17 (01:50): as in, something applied upstream breaks, and i have that patch, so i want to pass -R to reverse it
312c60a696ee6c11196fb7da47743b17 (01:50): or do i need to apply it, and generate a new patch
2abafdd6fabba43e49dd808e54d5f6bc (01:50): if it is failing why would you epatch it ?
b879fe28d1be411b86e6650416d51b4d (01:51): steev-laptop: man eutils.eclass, search for epatch
312c60a696ee6c11196fb7da47743b17 (01:51): langthang|work: apparently, im missing that manpage
312c60a696ee6c11196fb7da47743b17 (01:52): those would be nice to be installed with portage
74c761012c0f07003f60498f0c4eaf8c (01:52): pulled in via doc use flag...
312c60a696ee6c11196fb7da47743b17 (01:52): ill have to add it to just portage then :)
74c761012c0f07003f60498f0c4eaf8c (01:54): just heading off any "it's not there"
df899a89abd846dc05a29ddcfcaa11de (01:55): towel day is yet to come
